title: ğŸ” AWS IoT Jobs Explorer (Boto3)
learning_description:
This script helps you explore and understand AWS IoT Jobs in detail. You'll learn how
to inspect job configurations, monitor job executions across devices, and understand
job status reporting. This is essential for managing OTA deployments and troubleshooting
device update issues in production IoT environments.

warnings.debug_warning: âš ï¸  WARNING: Debug mode exposes sensitive information (ARNs, account IDs, API responses)

learning.job_status_tip: ğŸ’¡ Learning Tip: Job statuses indicate the overall progress of your OTA deployment.
learning.in_progress_tip: IN_PROGRESS jobs are actively deploying to devices.
learning.job_document_tip: ğŸ’¡ Learning Tip: The job document contains the instructions sent to devices.
learning.presigned_url_tip: Presigned URLs allow secure S3 access without device credentials.
learning.execution_status_tip: ğŸ’¡ Learning Tip: Job executions track individual device progress.
learning.status_details_tip: Status details contain device-reported information about success/failure.
learning.execution_progress_tip: ğŸ’¡ Learning Tip: Job execution status shows how your OTA deployment is progressing.
learning.succeeded_tip: SUCCEEDED means the device successfully completed the update.
learning.api_access_note: ğŸ’¡ Note: This script can now access job execution details for jobs in any status (including COMPLETED, FAILED, etc.)
learning.cancel_tip_1: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Use option 2 to view the canceled job details
learning.cancel_tip_2: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Use option 6 to delete the canceled job when ready
learning.delete_tip: ğŸ’¡ Tip: The job will no longer appear in job lists
learning.delete_tip_force: ğŸ’¡ Try again with force flag if job has executions
learning.delete_tip_cancel_first: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Only COMPLETED or CANCELED jobs can be deleted
learning.delete_tip_use_cancel: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Use option 5 to cancel IN_PROGRESS jobs first

cancel.warning: âš ï¸  WARNING: This action cannot be undone!
cancel.impact_in_progress: â€¢ IN_PROGRESS: {} devices (will complete current execution)
cancel.when_cancel_1: â€¢ QUEUED executions will NOT start (prevented from beginning)
cancel.when_cancel_2: â€¢ IN_PROGRESS executions will complete their current operation
cancel.when_cancel_3: â€¢ Job status changes to CANCELED (visible in job lists)
cancel.when_cancel_4: â€¢ You can still view job history and execution details
cancel.when_cancel_5: â€¢ Canceled jobs can be deleted later for cleanup
cancel.why_cancel_1: â€¢ Canceling preserves execution history for analysis
cancel.why_cancel_2: â€¢ Useful for troubleshooting why a job needed to stop
cancel.why_cancel_3: â€¢ Allows you to review what succeeded before cancellation
cancel.scenario_1: â€¢ Firmware update causing device issues â†’ Cancel to prevent more failures
cancel.scenario_2: â€¢ Wrong configuration deployed â†’ Cancel and create corrected job
cancel.scenario_3: â€¢ Testing job that should not reach production â†’ Cancel before it spreads

delete.warning: âš ï¸  WARNING: This will permanently delete the job and all execution history!
delete.deletion_removes_header: Job deletion permanently removes the job record from AWS IoT:
delete.deletion_removes_1: â€¢ Job configuration and document are deleted
delete.deletion_removes_2: â€¢ ALL execution history is permanently deleted
delete.deletion_removes_3: â€¢ This action cannot be undone - no recovery possible
delete.deletion_removes_4: â€¢ 'force' flag required if job has any execution history
delete.when_delete_1: â€¢ Cancel: Stop job but keep history for analysis
delete.when_delete_2: â€¢ Delete: Remove completed/canceled jobs to clean up
delete.when_delete_3: â€¢ Best practice: Cancel first, analyze, then delete
delete.why_force_1: â€¢ AWS protects against accidental data loss
delete.why_force_2: â€¢ Force flag confirms you understand execution history will be lost
delete.why_force_3: â€¢ Jobs without executions can be deleted without force
delete.scenario_1: â€¢ Test jobs after validation â†’ Delete to keep job list clean
delete.scenario_2: â€¢ Old completed jobs â†’ Delete after archiving results elsewhere
delete.scenario_3: â€¢ Canceled jobs after analysis â†’ Delete once you've documented findings
delete.force_required: âš ï¸  Force deletion required (job has execution history)

statistics.health_excellent: âœ… Excellent - Job is performing very well
statistics.health_good: âš ï¸  Good - Some failures detected, monitor closely
statistics.health_poor: âŒ Poor - High failure rate, investigate issues
statistics.health_critical: ğŸš¨ Critical - Majority of executions failing
statistics.learning_moment_header: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Job Statistics & Health
statistics.state_queued: â€¢ QUEUED: Job received but not started on device yet
statistics.state_in_progress: â€¢ IN_PROGRESS: Device is actively executing the job
statistics.state_succeeded: â€¢ SUCCEEDED: Job completed successfully on device
statistics.state_failed: â€¢ FAILED: Job execution failed (check device logs)
statistics.state_timed_out: â€¢ TIMED_OUT: Job exceeded timeout threshold
statistics.state_rejected: â€¢ REJECTED: Device rejected the job (version mismatch, etc.)
statistics.success_95_100: â€¢ 95-100%: Excellent - Job is working as expected
statistics.success_80_94: â€¢ 80-94%: Good - Minor issues, acceptable for most scenarios
statistics.success_50_79: â€¢ 50-79%: Poor - Significant issues need investigation
statistics.success_below_50: â€¢ <50%: Critical - Job likely has fundamental problems
statistics.pattern_timed_out: â€¢ High TIMED_OUT: Increase job timeout or optimize job document
statistics.pattern_rejected: â€¢ High REJECTED: Check device software versions and compatibility
statistics.pattern_failed: â€¢ High FAILED: Review job document syntax and device capabilities
statistics.practice_1: â€¢ Monitor statistics during rollout to catch issues early
statistics.practice_2: â€¢ Use SNAPSHOT target selection for gradual rollouts
statistics.practice_3: â€¢ Cancel jobs with >20% failure rate to prevent fleet-wide issues
statistics.rec_no_executions: â€¢ No executions found - job may not have started yet
statistics.rec_check_devices: â€¢ Check if target devices are online and connected
statistics.rec_verify_groups: â€¢ Verify thing group membership if using group targets
statistics.rec_canceled_early: â€¢ Job was canceled before any executions completed
statistics.rec_review_cancel: â€¢ Review cancellation reason to understand why it was stopped
statistics.rec_view_details: â€¢ Use option 2 to view full job details and history
statistics.rec_devices_removed: â€¢ All executions were removed (devices may have been deleted)
statistics.rec_verify_exist: â€¢ Verify target devices still exist in the registry
statistics.rec_in_progress: â€¢ Job is still in progress - no completed executions yet
statistics.rec_wait: â€¢ Wait for more executions to complete before analyzing
statistics.rec_monitor: â€¢ Monitor progress and check back later for updated statistics
statistics.rec_high_failure: â€¢ High failure rate detected - immediate action recommended
statistics.rec_investigate: â€¢ Use option 3 to investigate specific device failures
statistics.rec_check_logs: â€¢ Check device logs for error details
statistics.rec_consider_cancel: â€¢ Consider canceling job to prevent more failures (option 5)
statistics.rec_moderate_failure: â€¢ Moderate failure rate - investigation recommended
statistics.rec_monitor_closely: â€¢ Monitor closely as job continues
statistics.rec_continue_monitor: â€¢ Continue monitoring for any changes in success rate
statistics.rec_document: â€¢ Document successful patterns for future jobs
statistics.rec_good: â€¢ Job is performing well with minor issues
statistics.rec_review_failed: â€¢ Review failed executions to identify patterns
statistics.rec_acceptable: â€¢ Consider if failure rate is acceptable for your use case
statistics.rec_mixed: â€¢ Job has completed with mixed results
statistics.rec_understand_patterns: â€¢ Review execution details to understand failure patterns
